ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I didn't learn very much. I learned a bit about the history of education policy and politics in the United States, including key Supreme Court cases and government reports.
I learned how to evaluate social problems such as education and urban inequalities from multiple perspectives.
I learned all about the policy/law foundation of the modern education system.
Did not learn much at all. Would NOT recommend this class.
Important court cases and discourse that shaped access to education in the US
Not much that I couldnt have learned from a vox article
I learned about the history of the education system
Absolutely nothing. This class made no sense.
theories on differences in school quality
How to write a concise paper.
I learned about important court cases and documentation that have affected how education is structured today.
I learnt about educational law and school models

I learned a wide variety of things in the course such as the history of inequality within education, the fundamentals of a statistics such as modeling, and certain important court cases and their precendents.
You learn about this history of educational policy and we go through some basic statistics and legal cases.
I learned a lot about the education and court systems.
I learned about inequalities in education systems in the US.
I was able to learn about regression (which was helpful as a Psychology major), I also learned about pretty important education policy, including the Coleman Report etc.
Very broad survey of historical and enduring educational inequality in America, and the economic models used to measure it
Very general overview of the issues surrounding education inequality, including policy and legal issues.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class is extremely disorganized, almost to a ridiculous extent. I enjoyed lecture mostly because Professor Jaynes is a character and tells good stories. The grading of the assignments is also arbitrarily harsh and didn't make very much sense.
The professor is great and the material is engaging. There are no weaknesses to this course.

Strengths: Professor Jaynes is FANTASTIC, the reading are interesting, the lectures were engaging. Great class!

Weaknesses: I think there was too much focus on the specifics of mathematical models. They were brought up in class as if the class all had a strong background in them, which left those without experience confused. Understanding the math behind these studies was interesting, but the deep dive also took focus away from their implications/effects on the world.
Prof. Jaynes lectured using slides and had supplementary reading summaries. It was helpful but often times the lectures were dry and hard to focus in
I think this class was interesting but it was difficult to follow in a virtual environment. It felt a little bit disorganized. I do appreciate the flexibility the professor provided during covid

There are only weaknesses. The class was poorly organized, the lectures did not make sense (there was also no point in having the lectures be "mandatory attendance"), the homework grading was late and super harsh (for no reason). The assignments had the worst instructions ever and such hard maximum page limits -- which was all supposed to be done in groups. Literally terrible.

In general, the notes on canvas and the lectures were clear and concise

The assignments didn't alway reinforce the harder, theoretical concepts (i.e. tax and wealth) taught in class. A pset on that would have helped

strengths: interesting material
weaknesses: sometimes it felt repetitive; the professor completely changed the grading distribution in the last week of the course.

Weakness:
This course is extremely subjective. Most assignments are graded based on whether or not you repeated what the Professor wants to hear, rather than if you formed a coherent argument. Slightly disagreeing with the viewpoint of the lecture/Professor usually results in points taken off for arbitrary reasons. When asked why points were taken off, the TAs usually cannot explain why. 
There are group projects, but unless you have a great group prepare to do all if not most of the work. Despite requiring us to write down what each member contributed, there is no accountability and the same grades are assigned to everyone regardless of contribution.
Strength:
The TAs were very responsive when emailed about questions regarding the assignments.
I thought it could have been more structured and clearly mapped out to give some overall direction.

Sometimes the lectures felt a bit unorganized.  Additionally, the lecture slides were not posted on canvas and it would've been nice to have a look at the slides before or after the lecture for review.
Great lecturer who is really understanding but super disorganized with assignments and whats expected in them

This course is very disorganized and the grading seems kind of arbitrary to me. When I asked for a rubric on how assignments are graded, I was told there wasnt one. I would have appreciated more guidance and direction in the course. The group assignments were also a mess because there wasnt really a way to communicate who did what work  definitely left me feeling frustrated because no matter how it was divided, everyone got the same grade.

I liked that Professor Jaynes provided lecture notes that outlined each class quite well.
The sections felt a bit forced, grading could be made more clear.
The strength of this course is that it is quite low work load while still teaching students that care about the material a lot. It could be improved in its organization.

This class is on a fascinating topic and I found Professor Jaynes to be an engaging lecturer, however, this course is extremely disorganized. Throughout the semester the syllabus changed four times (some of which was just said in class for a minute and then moved on). One of the last times it was changed was on the last day of classes, giving us quite literally no time to improve our performance in the class except for the final. The assignments were also very unclear. The prompts were not straightforward, but no rubric was provided. And all of the assignments were graded very harshly (the average for the first assignment was a 75). Lastly, most of the work in the class is done in group projects. This means writing 5 -10 pg essays in group projects, which was an extremely frustrating and challenging project. All in all this course needs a massive overhaul in its structure in order to improve -- have a clear syllabus from the get go, clear rubric for each assignment, and make group assignments minimal.
Very poorly organized for learning. Lecture notes on top of a synchronous lecture on top of readings and homework assignments. The syllabus was changed several times throughout the semester

The biggest weakness of this course is the group projects. Especially in the middle of a pandemic, and in a class that many students take with the Credit/D/Fail option, introducing group homework as well as a group final project (which counted for 40% of the grade) was destined to fail. Students were in very different circumstances and had varying incentives to do well on the group assignments which led to extreme difficulty for those who were trying to coordinate the group and get a decent grade.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Live Zoom lecture was fine.
Although face to face interactions can never be replaced, the recorded zoom lectures and online lecture notes were very helpful for someone enrolled online.

The quizzes were a good idea but shouldve been extra credit or just review from the start

The group projects were not good in the pandemic environment at all
Virtual was alright.
The flexibility of office hours helped immensely during COVID.

The lecture notes were very helpful and needed. I though this was a great way to get students prepared for the Zoom lecture. The group assignments were awful. Its very hard to get everyone to meet over Zoom sometimes and the most of the assignments could have been individual. Also not being able to select your group when everything is over Zoom is also really annoying and adds an unnecessary layer of stress.
I thought the lectures were quite good
The covid measures were fine for pandemic learning.
I liked the fact that lectures were recorded, and I did enjoy the mandatory section. I think this class was less effected by the COVID-19 policies as it was the disorganization.

I appreciated some flexibility towards the end of the semester (leading to a major syllabus change) but it would have been nice if the prof figured out what the structure of the class would be (accommodated for COVID) and stuck with it

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: There's very little work, but I don't feel like I know whether I'm going to get an A, which is very annoying because the grading is weirdly harsh.
I would recommend this course to others because it looks at problems from different perspectives and gives you a better understanding of current issues as a whole.

Yes! Professor Jaynes is fantastic. He is keenly intelligent, yet has the emotional intelligence to understand the audience with whom he is having conversations. I've never had a professor who I respect so much. Take this class for Professor Jaynes, highly recommend.
No
NO.
No, its like a mermaid it tricks u into thinking its easy and then murders u with bad grading policies
Not really. I found it hard to engage with the material during the pandemic. I think it might be better in person though
No. Your grade is just such a toss up it's not worth it.
Yes, the course is interesting if you're interested in thinking about why certain (public) schools do better than others
Yes - if you are interested in the materia (education, law)l + need an economics elective
I would only recommend this course to another student if they are really interested in learning about inequalities present in the education system and do not have much knowledge about it.
Yes, the content was incredibly interesting.
I would recommend this course to someone interested in learning a wide variety of topics surrounding education inequality.
Probably not
No. I think there are other economics classes that are more interesting. The workload wasnt too intense but the disorganization made the class harder than it needed to be.
A very interesting course!
gut
I would recommend this class to any econ student that is interested in the topic.

In its current form no. This class was extremely stressful, as you rarely had an understanding of what was required, where you stood in the class, what the teacher was expecting from you. At certain points it was even difficult to determine in what weeks you would have an assignment due. Maybe if you were an Econ major and this was a required elective, but even then, I am sure you can find better ones.
Not really, I learned very little; if you need an Econ or Ed Studies credit

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: A couple of mandatory Zoom sections during the semester.
Zoom lectures and discussion sections
Several mandatory section sessions.
Mandatory discussion sections on specific weeks
virtual lecture + virtual section
recorded
The various ways to analyze discrimination and inequality in the education system, specifically using economic tools.
There were two mandatory discussions sessions we had to attend on top of the live virtual lecture
It was a recorded lecture with a couple sections every few weeks
Lecture with Section
NA
We also had in person section.
We also had two synchronous sections throughout the course of the semester
